data.message: Thanks for the Amazon gift cards tsp! This was an informative and motivating three months, I hope it will help me finally break my habit for good, and I really enjoyed getting paid to learn!
Thank you, 10340! We are so glad to hear that and wish you all the best in ending your habit. Please don't hesitate to reach out and use us as a resource! :)

Hello TSP members! Many thanks to those of you who have done our first follow-up survey sent out two weeks ago. For those of you who haven't, don't forget to check your email and complete it for a $20 gift card! You’ll earn an additional $20 at the end if you fill out all surveys!
All done
So when do we receive our dollar a comment compensation? All I've received so far is one survey for 20 dollars.
Sorry for my lack of contributing I have been busy lately with fire's and my job. I would like to point out that I have not smoked a cigarette in over a month and I haven't had any cravings
That is wonderful news, 10356! Keep up the great work (y)

Just a friendly reminder to check your email and fill out the first follow-up survey that we sent out last week. Remember, you'll receive $20 for completing it and will receive an additional $20 at the end if you complete all follow-up surveys!

Hello TSP members! Yesterday's post concludes our 90-day program. Please check your email this week for our first follow-up survey. You will receive a $20 gift card upon completion. We hope that our Facebook group has been enjoyable, educational, and life-changing in some way, whether it be a shift in your perspective towards smoking, or a commitment towards a healthier, smoke-free life. All of us at TSP have enjoyed reading your comments and interacting with you online, and we truly thank you for your participation.Although we will no longer be posting daily, you are welcome to remain in this secret group and access all of the content we've shared over the past 90 days. Furthermore, we're still available to answer any questions/concerns about smoking, and we're open to any feedback/suggestions you may have for our program.Again, from all of us at TSP, thank you and good luck in your future endeavors!
Nice

data.message: #62: Imagine you’re an executive for a large tobacco company who's been asked by a child to present at her school on Career Day. What would you say about your company’s mission? What would you tell the kids about smoking? #knowyourself

I would tell then the truth. I would explain what my job is, what I do but I would also explain that the products my company makes are for adults and that they do have risks. I would also tell them that like any other company we are trying to make money and we advertise to an adult market.
Wow thats a good question that i have no answer to. Honestly i would love to ask someone that works for a tobacco company but i don't know anyone that does
I would tell them the health risks and remind them you must be a legal adult to purchase or use tobacco products.

#54: Bars and restaurants across the country are banning smoking. Is it legal to smoke in restaurants or bars in your state? How does it affect you? #smokingaffectsall

No and I'm glad for that
It doesn't really affect me. I don't go out much.
No smoking allowed inside only outside and its cool with me the last thing I want when I'm eating is someone's smoke in my face

Thanks for watching the video and sharing your thoughts!
#55: Who are you a role model for? Siblings, children, nieces, nephews? How would their lives change if you decided to quit? #smokingaffectsall

I moved out of state, so my nieces and nephew won't be exposed. As for the topic of children, that's not something I'm planning on doing in front of them, ever. Whether I quit or cut back, I won't expose them to toxins purposefully.
I don't have a lot of little people in my life.
My siblings, I try not to smoke in front of them
I do my best to not condone it, and hopefully I can quit to reinforce that idea

My nieces my parents are raising my sisters daughter and she asks me all the time of I've quit or tells me I shouldn't smoke when I babysit her and step outside for a break. She's precious to me as all get out, been involved with her heavily since her birth. It would be great to be able to look into that adorable face and tell her I quit.
Well I'm quitting in hope it will encourage my girlfriend to quit so I might be a role model for her in that sense
No one but myself
#53: If you labeled yourself as a nonsmoker, how would your self-image change? How would you see yourself differently if you no longer smoked? #knowyourself
Honestly not at all. My self image isn't touched by smoking, it doesn't change who I am to myself.
I don't think I'd see myself any differently as a nonsmoker.

I would feel better. Knowing what I'm doing to myself is quite possibly the worst part of being informed about the dangers of smoking. I would feel less self harming and healthier. Not to mention, I would have a lot more money for other things!
I would see myself being a littler healthier that's for sure
I haven't quite thought about that yet
Hey guys sorry my phone broke and I haven't been able to get to a computer but idk I guess I would be proud of myself

data.message: #47: According to the CDC, 126 million nonsmokers are exposed to second-hand smoke, and the most exposure occurs in vehicles and homes. Who may have inhaled smoke in your car or home? #smokingaffectsall
My grandmother, my father and my little cousins
My boyfriend and family.
I don't let anyone smoke in my car and I smoke only outdoors. So anyone outside with me I guess.
I don't smoke inside
Family and friends

I make it a point to never smoke inside and used to take long walks so that there'd be no leftover smoke on me when I used to live under the same roof as my nieces. I also only ever smoked in the cars of smokers who were already smoking. But current situation, my girlfriend is exposed, but I make the exposure as minimal as possible because I'm trying to quit
Thanks for sharing!
#46: Lots of smoker's report that they smoke more often when they're stressed. What can you do differently to deal with daily stressors in your smoke-free future? #balance
Exercise hands down its the best way in my opinion to deal with stress. In any form
I have different breathing things I do and I listen to music when I'm stressed because it helps bring it down.
Exercise, breathing routines, not stressing out over menial things
I don't know. That's my biggest problem. Lol maybe deep breathing or distractions instead of smoking?
I'm not entirely sure, but I'll do my best to find something.
Go to a spa
Great ideas!

#45: Remember that small step towards quitting you chose 2 weeks ago? Try out a different one and tell the group how it worked out for you. #freeyourself • Delay your first cigarette of the day by 10 minutes• Limit your smoking to one or two places only • Smoke fewer cigarettes each day• Quit smoking for 24 hours
I only smoke outside now. I completely stopped smoking inside my apartment
Smoke fewer ciggeretts each day
I smoke one per day, only on the balcony and in the car. I can do the quitting for the 24 hours easily, I smoked my last one recently. I'm gonna see how long I can last.
I've only smoked two cigarettes today! That's progress!
I haven't been buying any cigarettes lately I'm trying really hard
Before today I haven't had a cigarette in about 3 days, sadly I relapsed today
Glad to hear about the progress you all are making! Keep up the good work! (y)

#43: Many states and organizations are releasing anti-tobacco media campaigns, like this one from the CDC. How you feel about these ads being made public on television and billboards? #smokingaffectsall
data.name: Amanda's Story - Tips From Former Smokers
data.caption: www.cdc.gov
data.description: Amanda smoked during pregnancy and her baby was born two months early. Her full story and her videos are part of CDC's Tips From Former Smokers campaign.

data.message: I understand that they are trying to educate people about the bad effects of smoking but I feel like those of us who smoke, we know it's bad for us. We know this can happen or that can happen and I feel like I don't need it consistently shoved at me that smoking is bad. I know!! I make a choice to smoke, knowing the side affects. Stop reminding me. I get it.

I think it's great that they're trying to get people to abstain from smoking, but it's more of the same, nobody is going to argue that smoking tobacco is good for you, but people make decisions and shouldn't be patronized or considered less of a person for it

When ever i see a commercial about ciggeretts I change the channel cause they scare the shit outa me. Like the ones with the lady that has the hole in her throat and talks with that machine or the one with the lady who has to wear a colonoscopy bag or whatever its called. I look at those commercials and get scared that ima end up just like them or worse. I hate those commercials but I guess there good in a way, they somewhat motivate me to quit.

I think them being made public is a great idea. The phrase goes "out of sight, out of mind". If we stop showing people cigarettes are bad, that in itself could increase smoking. Availability=good. Smoking while pregnant=bad.
Sharing a story like that is fine. It's seems like it's leaning away from a lot the scare tactics anti smoking campaigns go for

I think that while personal experience stories are not only more sincere and effective, I think  people are less likely to pay attention and grasp the effect. Meanwhile I feel the "horror" tactics and even the "abuse" symbolism (making a cigarette sound like an abusive boyfriend) are annoying and in some cases stupid, but different tactics reach out to and affect different people. However, I will voice I think it's wrong to use the ocassional graphic commercial, because the images can traumatize a child, yeah, it may teach them to stay away from tabacco, but the congratulations comes with being responsible for the irrational fears , nightmares, night terrors, potential hallucinations and other possible psychosis. So seeing something that is less of a miniature horror movie in the eyes of children (and honestly cringe worthy of some adults, like that teeth pulling one? Ew.) is a step in the right direction, but may lose the initial attention of viewers. I can tell you in elementary school they brought a glass truck holding a smashed car and a screen showing the "story" and face of the victim. Yeah, I can tell you I never drank and drive and I've prevented people from doing so, but there's no saying it was because of that shitty, non-kid friendly exposure. What I can tell you is I went to sleep as a kid seeing that face a lot and needing one of my parents to stay in my room. I am whole-heartedly for not traumatizing children to make a point that could have been made through other means.
Awesome discussion! Thank you for sharing your views.
#42: Has smoking changed the way you view yourself? What is your self-identity as someone who smokes? #knowyourself
No it really hasn't changed. I just see myself as someone who smokes.
Idk i still see my self the same i just smoke now
I see myself exactly as the same, my self image hasn't been effected.
Idk, gonna go against popular opinion so far. There is a lot of stigma attached to being a smoker. Like you're "dirty" or something.
I'd have to say I view myself as someone who is a slightly worse role model for others when I smoke
I see myself as the same as I was, just with the added stench of nicotine
Thank you so much for sharing.

#41: Think about when, where, and why you choose to smoke when you do. Do those situations have in anything common? Pick one of the following situations (or tell us your own) and tell us why that circumstance almost always ends with a cigarette for you. #beingconscious • When you’re drinking coffee• When you’re driving• When you’re drinking alcohol• When you’re talking on the phone• When you’re feeling down
Driving because it makes me anxious and nervous.
When I'm feeling sad When I'm drinking or smoking marijuanaWhen I'm bored And when I'm with fellow smokers
Triggers in order:-when I'm angry-when I'm upset-when I'm depressed or dissociating-when other smokers smoke around me (I joke and call it the 'chill factor.')
After eating.
When I'm at shows, and seeing everyone else smoking a cigarette outdoors
When i drink i turn into a chain smoker idk why but they make me feel so much better and they taste amazing when your drunk
Thanks for identifying your triggers! Knowing them will be helpful to avoid tempting situations if/when you're ready to quit.
#44: What are some of your favorite qualities about yourself? How does smoking fit (or not fit) with that image of you? #balance
I'm compassionate and I like to help others. I don't really see how smoking affects either of those
I'm a writer, smoking doesn't really effect that though
Im a cook and i take care of the elderly ao i guess it could effect both in a way

I'm an artist and an intellect..I guess it fits the stereotype for the "messy artist"? But no, really, I don't see how smoking does anything to my own self image. I'm at peace with what I'm doing to myself- however I am not at the very least content with what it can do to my loved ones.
I pride myself on being very hygienic. Smoking is anything but. :/

I'm an entertainer, and it fits in with the image of one on their down time. Or when I'm out at events, there's a general scene if people huddled in groups together outside with trauma of cigarette smoking lingering though the air
Do you think you will EVER be ready to quit smoking? Why? Why not? #TDII

data.message: #39: Children can’t really distinguish between vapor and smoke. What they see are important adults in their life setting an example for how to take care of themselves, what they spend their money on, and their attitudes about addictive substances. Would you hide your e-cig smoking from a child? #ecig
Ideally when I am at the point of being a father I won't be using any tobacco products
Idk maybe or i could try explaining it to them

No, I wouldn't hide it. I would give them age appropriate answers for any questions they might ask but I don't believe in teaching children to hide things. To me it sets up a president for future behavior.
Hiding in my opinion makes things worse. It's best to talk to your child about everything

I wouldn't hide it. Do you hide a glass of wine at dinner from a child? No, there is an age appropriate explanation for most anything. You can always say it's something adults over 18 do and when you're 18 if you want you can try it. Not until then :)

Not at all, though I would try to keep myself from doing it around them if possible, just to limit exposure so they're not desensitized, but it's not going to be a huge secret, if that day ever comes. The plan is that it won't.
I wouldn't hide it, but I would control my use around them
Thanks for discussing! You raise some good points.
#38: What have you heard about the patch, a form of Nicotine Replacement Therapy? Would you ever use it? #beingconscious
I have used it and for me it just didn't seem to help a whole lot and that's when I could get them to stay on.
My roommate used it and it worked from him but he said it stings the skin
I used them for about two weeks. The only bad side effect I noticed was VERY vivid dreams. Like scary vivid. I would wake up thinking they were real. Doctors said that is common on nicotine patches
It doesn't work for me, I still had the urge to at least vape. I may have less of a need for nicotine as I do have an oral fixation
I don't have any desire to use the nicotine patch simply because o just don't want to try it
I dont know much about them but I know I wouldn't use it
I would never use the patch. I completely agree with 10342
Thanks for sharing!
#37: With all the new Tobacco Legislation, most workplaces are now smoke-free. Do you think it's better for society as a whole to have smoke-free workplaces? #smokingaffectsall

Yes, if it's a smoke free workplace like say a college campus, hospital, school ground. Doesn't make sense to have a designated smoking area even for employees of the whole property is smoke free. Sends a mixed message otherwise.
Yes, it's unsanitary and unhealthy to smoke inside of public buildings
Yes, it's unsanitary and not everyone wants to be around smoking.

I think it's for the best. I've traveled a lot; in Salt Lake City's Airport in Utah they have smoking rooms that have suction to keep the smoke and air in, but circulated..I thought that was the coolest thing and a brilliant designated smoking area. In theory that's the only good kind of smoking area, as far as not exposing others and the environment, but it's expensive and smoke particles will still stick to clothes and other porous surfaces like hair. So all around, it's best to have a completely smoke free area available to the public.

I work at a hospital that recently started a smoke free policy. Since then I've seen a lot less hospital workers who smell like cigarettes in their work environment. It was a smart choice because it establishes a cleaner and therefore safier medical environment
Yeah of course non smokers shouldn't have to inhale the second hand smoke. It could also help smokers cut down or maybe even quit all together.
I think it's a good idea. It might also help people wanting to quit just kick it completely if they are unable to smoke at work.
Awesome points, you guys!
#36: Check out how one Tobacco company called young adult smokers "replacement smokers" on record. What does it feel like to be part of a big, expensive marketing strategy? #reflection
Well it sucks, but a lot of companies view people as only dollar signs
Tobacco companies aren't the only ones who view us this way. Most big companies just see dollar signs not the people they are affecting
Well its kind of expected but still really messed up
They have a point.
Capitalism. Not suprised in the least, many companies do shady things to stay in demand and on the top- you'd be suprised at how dark things can get, so this doesn't really shock me.
I'm not surprised. Is there a source for this document?
It's a money game. They need to continue making money and with the statistics they have, they have a very valid, although very disgusting, point.

10356 - these quotes are from previously secret tobacco industry documents that have been made public and are now being housed in the Legacy Tobacco Documents Library here at UCSF (https://industrydocuments.library.ucsf.edu/tobacco/) - here are some more interesting quotes from these documents, if you're interested: http://the84.org/get-the-facts/tobacco-executive-quotes/
thank you so much for the reply! I'll definitely be looking at these.

It honestly doesn't really affect me. Whether you smoke or not, you are a consumer of something and companies profit from you. The company isn't forcing you to smoke so it's your choice to let them profit from you
What a great discussion! (y)

#33: Social situations can make it hard to not smoke, especially when alcohol is involved. Does alcohol affect your smoking? How would you change that if you wanted to cut down or quit? #beingconscious
Not a big drinker :/ just frequent establishments that are non smoking when you're out drinking. If it's not a bar with available ashtrays you won't smoke!
Not a big drinker and I don't frequent bars much.
Legally I can't drink yet. :p I don't have much to worry about with this.
Alcohol makes me smoke more sadly, but I don't drink often so I would rather smoke when I drink than smoke all the time
I hardly ever drink. But on the few occasions that do I do tend to smoke more.
Booze makes me chain smoke really bad it's really quite ridiculous
Yes alcohol makes me smoke more so in order to quit smokingbi will have to quit drinking too
It's hard to not want to smoke when I'm drunk and I see other people smoking

Alcohol definitely causes me to smoke more, I literally use it as a chaser. So I would have to just keep myself from situations where there's alcohol until I feel confident enough that it wouldn't make me slip up.
Thanks for sharing, you guys!
#34: Let's see how many comebacks you guys can come up with for this ever-popular drawback to quitting. What will you tell yourself if this thought crosses your mind? #balance
I'm a curvy, short Italian girl so that's always a fear of mine. Not much will change.
My weight fluctuates anyway, I'm not too scared. Growing up, I've learned you can lose weight faster than you gain it if you try, so it will be a matter of making myself try if worst comes to worst.
I'm not afraid of gaining a little weight
Crunches.
Im not worried about gaining weight
I'm more afraid of entering my grave early than I am of a few extra lbs.
I would rather gain the few extra pounds than take more years off my life than I already have.

I honestly just think it's one of those things that people use as an excuse to not quit. You can always lost the weight, but you can't erase the damage done to your health caused by smoking!! Gaining weight after I quit is the least of my worries lol
Awesome comebacks, you all! :D
#40: How do you think your home environment would change if you quit smoking? #beingconscious
There would be significantly less cigarette butts
It would be healthier and more inviting because it wouldn't smell so bad.
My house would smell like my wax cubes instead of smoke and that would be great lol.
Less chance of another fire over here

Ewwww.  Thousands. That part always makes me feel bad. I'll go camping or hiking and see butts everywhere. But I can't get angry. I've thrown my share out the window driving too. We need to be more responsible for our planet.
Idk i feel like it would be the same i use ash trays even outside i guess the air would be less polluted
I wouldn't have a nasty cigarette butt bottle on the balcony. Seeing how nasty it is happens to be one of my incentives to quit
Sorry guys - I'm late for today's session. Have you ever noticed a connection between smoking and your mood? Is there an emotional state that gets you to light up more frequently? #TDII
Sorry guys, I've got to run for today. I'll come online tomorrow to see if there are any questions. Have a good evening!
Hi guys - I'll be online for a while now. Let me know if you have any questions or respond to my question on smoking and mood above if you'd like.
#35: When you read this statistic, who in your life do you start thinking about? Friends, family, coworkers? #smokingaffectsall
I think of my younger siblings, sometimes I smoke in front of them and I need to stop that
I think about my friends that don't smoke and my little cousins.

I think about my family and my girlfriend - the people who want me to quit the most and the people who were most exposed to second hand smoke by me. Regardless of smoking outside, particles stick to clothing and hair (etc) and linger. This post brings up a lot of fear and the reason I want to quit.

Honestly I don't think too much of anyone when I read this. Maybe I'm selfish, or maybe because I smoke near other smokers or away from all the non smokers. Really the only thing that concerns me in relation to second hand is that I might accidentally drop a hot ash while smoking and starting a fire.

I think about everyone that doesn't smoke that I smoke around. Makes me feel pretty shitty. Also pushes me to want to try harder to quit, not only am I affecting my own health, but also my friend's and family's as well.
My friends and family i guess but most of the time i smoke outside away from everyone else
Maybe my boyfriend. I don't smoke around people who don't smoke, most of the time.
My dogs honestly! Lol everyone in this house smokes except them, and they can't exactly crack the window now can they?

data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: Hi everyone, the next Q&A session will be on Wednesday. See you then!

data.message: #31: Turn it up a notch. Tell someone special about the small step you tried yesterday. How did it go? #freeyourself
I sadly don't have very many special people in my life

My girlfriend is the only person I'm constantly around. My mother is really happy for me and after talking to my girlfriend she's expressed that she's proud and understands that this could take a while. I'm thankful for the support in my life, whether it helps or not.
I've told my grandma and she thinks that it's great!
My fiance thinks it's great!
My boyfriend thinks it's great.
Well i only got me so i told myself and I was really proud
My gal knows I've been doing well see's been seeing it in person
Bf thinks it's great. He smokes too. Would like him to be looking into quitting as much as I am :/
So happy to hear about the positive response you got from your supporters! :)

#12: Did you know that the number of non-smokers affected by second hand smoke is more than double the number of actual smokers in the U.S.? Who is affected by your second hand smoke? #smokingaffectsall
My dogs. I have no children. But my dogs are forced to inhale it. Not very fair for them :(
It would be my grandmother and my dad. My dad just recently stopped smoking. Otherwise most everyone else around me smokes.
I usually smoke outside with nobody around except for fellow smokers
My boyfriend, but other than that most everyone I know smokes.
who evers around me i guess i try not to smoke infront of children other than that my family and friends
Just people at shows for me, but I prefer to smoke away from non smokers
I try to smoke alone, but it doesn't always work that way, and the smoke particles stick to clothing and linger. Second hand smoke is the exact reason I'm trying to quit
I really only smoke outside so my guess would be no one.

Wow, I missed this one! But I was not aware it is double, but I guess that makes sense if you smoke around people. A lot of people are affected by mine, unfortunately. :( I am going to only try to smoke outside now!
Thank you so much for sharing.
#27: If you want to get info about how to quit smoking, where do you go? How do you know the source is true? #beingconscious
I talk to former smokers and listen to how they managed to give up smoking
I talk to people I know who've quit smoking and I've also called those quit now hotlines

I feel former smokers are the best source, they know how tough it is to quit and are less likely to make the decision and commitment of quitting sound like a cakewalk. If you want the technical stuff on why, there's the Internet (.org and .gov for most reliability) but I think if you want the how and truth on the struggle, a person with experience is the best source.
I agree with the above previous smokers are the best source

The states usually have an office you can contact to get help with quitting. Unbiased therapy, phone support, and they offer coupons and some stop smoking aids for free! Pretty good resource! For example my state has the Arkansas quit line.
Former smokers for sure. They've been through it. They know.
I go to my primary doctor they have tons of info and i trust my doctor

I usually ask ex smokers because they've been in the same position as us and I feel like they have the best insight...except the ones that say they quit cold turkey lol I don't know how anyone can do that!
Thanks for sharing! :D

#26: Studies of former smokers show that it is extremely helpful to know where, when, and why you are most likely to smoke. That way, when you’re quitting your habit, you can plan ahead for those situations and won’t be caught off guard. Which situation are you most likely to smoke in? #beingconscious • When you first wake up in the morning• When you’re stressed• When you’re socializing with friends• When you’re tired• When you’re in a bad mood
When I'm stressed, when I'm having anxiety, when I'm driving and right after I eat.
My biggest trigger is any emotional and mental distress, whether it be anger, extreme sadness, or anxiousness.
My biggest trigger has been being extremely stressed out and miserable lately
I smoke a lot at shows or when people are stressing out around me
When I'm in the car and after I eat are my biggest triggers. I also smoke more when I'm stressed or upset.
After a meal. That's a big one.
When im in a bad mood/stressed and when im socializing with friends. Oh and when im using the bathroom lmao theres nothing better than a smoke on the toilet idk about yall but it deff helps lol
When I'm bored, in a bad mood, stressed, driving, or hanging out with friends.
Thanks for identifying your triggers! It is helpful to know so that you can avoid these triggers when/if you're ready to quit.

#25: Take a few deep breaths to center yourself the next time your cravings are getting to you. Try it out today and tell us how it went. Were you able to put off lighting up for a little while? #feelinghealthy
I've only had one cigarette so far today. I've done a lot of breathing and distraction...like listening to music and watching tv.
Ill let you know as soon as i try it
It's not working, I've noticed that recently my tobacco use has increased due to a lot of stress at home

I was able to put it off for a while. I woke up at 8am today and distracted myself until almost noon, which I know isn't too long, but for it being my first cigarette of the day it felt like it was a pretty long time. I even took a trip in the car without smoking one which was HUGE to me. It's one of my biggest triggers. I did cave though when I felt myself getting really  angry and upset, to the point I found myself screaming into a pillow!! (I had a somewhat stressful morning, so that didn't help) but as soon as I hit it a few times I felt myself calm down a little, but I also felt my chest tighten and I felt my breathing being affected. Sorry for this post being a bit long, but I felt like today I came to some realizations!

I haven't smoked today, I've been trying to put it off and use the techniques. I'm not going to lie though, I could really use a cigarette, I lost one of the kittens I've taken in to panleukopenia, the other came up positive for it too, and it's been horrific to watch what happens to such a fragile baby even when you try to nurse it. I don't think breathing methods is going to help me cope short term.
It did help me put off smoking for a few hours!
I had a drag today which is a bummer because I spent 9 days not smoking :(
Doesn't really help me out

My schedule was all f'ed up today. I honestly didn't even think about breathing techniques. My cigarettes and energy drinks were everybody's friend today. Without them I probably would have yelled at more than a few people.
Thanks for sharing your experience! Sorry to those of you who had a tough day.

#24: Big Tobacco is advertising e-cigarettes as a safer and better way to smoke, but studies have shown that they still contain toxins. Why do you think so many people are ready to adopt them even before proper research has been conducted? #ecig
E cigs are a generally cheaper alternative

It's hard to ignore the hazards of smoking cigarettes with all the research. My grandmother won't stop smoking now because she says back in her day they weren't told it was bad for them. She uses that excuse to this day, despite the mounting body of evidence that proves its hazards. Ignorance is bliss, as the saying goes.

Because they are cheaper than cigarettes in some cases and people like to believe they can still 'smoke' without the damage of actually smoking cigarettes but because there isn't a lot of research on e-cigs so we don't actually know what kind of damage they can do.

Ecigs are not only the "seemingly" safe alternative, but also the alternative that is easier to hide. Hide it in your sleeve and hold your breath long enough and you could smoke practically anywhere without anyone realizing.
Maybe they think its saver for the people around them. You know cause its not real smoke just vapor i guess idk
In Seattle it was legal to smoke e-cigs indoors for a little while so a lot of my friends switched for that reason. But it is also cheaper and at least seems safer.
It's because people like buzz words and will jump at anything nowadays if it involves healthier, or at least here in California.

I think it's because people who smoke them that already were smoking cigarettes already know about the health risks and are already in the mind set of not really worrying them, ecigs being known as "safer" doesn't really help the cause either. Like other people have said they're a lot cheaper too, and you can sometimes smoke inside, so I think that draws people to them as well.
I think that ecigs are highly advertised as being more safe to smoke than cigarettes which in my opinion is a bunch of crap.
Great points, everyone!

#32: It’s not just your friends and family who may want you to quit! The Surgeon General’s office, the Center for Disease Control (CDC), and other national organizations are urging people to quit smoking. How does it feel to see our society moving towards a tobacco-free mindset? #smokingaffectsall
I think it's a good thing to have society moving this way. Maybe we can have a generation thst doesn't smoke.
It will definitely cut down on that pesky pollution thing
I appreciate the idea that there are many means for education and support available to those wanting to quit.
Would be nice too see less butts everywhere

I'm a little conflicted about this topic. On the one hand it would be nice to see fewer butts everywhere and less people dying from lung cancer. On the other, smoking doesn't do nearly as much damage to the communities in which people who smoke live as use of other more serious drugs might. I think the push toward quitting smoking should be every individuals own decision not one forced upon them by their society.
Good! I would love to live long enough to see a generation without cigarette smokers!
It's great hopefully it will help me quit for good

#30: Baby steps are required to conquer smoking once and for all. Pick one of these small steps to try and post your choice here. #freeyourself • Smoke five fewer cigarettes each day• Delay your first cigarette of the day by 10 minutes• Limit your smoking to one or two places only • Quit smoking for 24-hours
Smoke five fewer cigarettes a day
I've been limiting my smoking to only home and at work so there's that
Quit for 24 hours.

I've been doing the 24 hour one. I try to take at least a day between every cigarette or two I smoke in a day and then try to delay my next by "procrastinating" on going out to smoke next, which surprisingly can work a lot.
I need more baby steps I've been do by all of these already! :p
Ill limit my smoking places to only 2 places
Maybe try not smoking for twenty four hours. Or putting off my cigarettes
I've been doing the procrastination! I think it's working great, especially while I'm at work

#29: Hoping to be prepared for withdrawal symptoms? Learn about what to expect at the link below. How are you planning to deal with these symptoms when you decide to quit? #balance http://buff.ly/1HOwXoL
Talking about how I'm feeling, maybe seeing a doctor and find something positive to replace the habit of smoking.
I'll likely be fine when the time comes, I've been through withdrawal before
I'll do my best to dissociate with videogames, that always helps me forget my immediate surroundings and situations. Not "healthy" but effective for me.
I'm going to try my best to tough it out
Ill just take it like a man I guess idk i dont even think ill get withdrawal symptoms.
We'll see. I struggle with most of these symptom now, so I foresee myself being slightly more angry. That's about it.
I don't know. I'm already pretty on edge most of the time. I think just talking about how I feel will help me as well as the others around me. I think gum might help, honestly.

The part of nicotine withdraw that plays with emotion is going to be really tough for me. Like I have said before, I was diagnosed as bipolar a few years ago and have finally been able to, within the last year, not be on medicine and I'm very afraid quitting will trigger it and send me into a downhill spiral :l
Have you ever tried to quit or reduce your smoking? Which strategy did you choose and how did it go? #TDII
I tried to quit with nicotine patches once. Worked for about two weeks. It was not successful :/
Thanks for sharing 10340 - what do you think went wrong that time? And what would you do differently in your next attempt?

You know, I honestly think it was a matter of will power. I know how horrible they are for me. I have an underlying medical condition that would greatly benefit from me quitting. Several family members have died of cigarette related illnesses. But something makes me keep reaching for a cigarette in times of great stress. I don't understand it!
I quit cold turkey before  and it was going good it lasted several months

10340 - sounds like you have plenty of motivation for quitting but it's hard to make it stick. If you want we work on coming up with useful alternatives for times of stress. What else have you tried in stressful situations and how did it go?
10354 thanks for sharing - sounds like you made it work for quite a while, that's great! What worked well during your smoke free time and what did not work so well?
Staying away from other smokers helped out a lot

I'm not very good at managing my own stress. Is there a correlation between poor stress management and smoking? Perhaps we that are addicted are having such difficulties in quitting for more than one reason? Or a few underlying factors make us more susceptible?
Agreed 10354 - this can be a very useful strategy. How would you go about quitting in a future attempt? What approach will you choose?
Im not sure as of right now

10340, yes stress can make it very hard to stay smoke free. Here are some things you could try: Go for a walk.Spend time in nature.Call a good friend. Play a competitive game of tennis or raquetball. Write in your journal. Take a long bath.  Light scented candles. Savor a warm cup of coffee or tea. Play with a pet. Work in your garden. Get a massage. Curl up with a good book.  Listen to music.Watch a comedy.
I know i gotta stay away from smokers and pretty much anything that angers me
Any of these sound useful 10340? There are plenty of ideas here if you want to read more on the topic of stress management http://www.helpguide.org/articles/stress/stress-management.htm
They all sound pretty nice actually :) thank you, I'll give this a try in the next few days!
10354 sounds like stress management may actually also be useful for you. Is there anything smokers around you could do that would be helpful?

10340 - great! This is definitely a learning process and some things may not work for you but others might! Sometimes it can just be very useful to find out that we can cope with a situations without a cigarette when we didn't think we could.
No all the smokers i know just say there gonna quit but dont end up doing it
10354 do you think it would be helpful if they didn't smoke around you and didn't offer you cigarettes? Could you ask them to do that?
I've got to run. See you next week - bye!

#28: In a survey of 800 New Yorkers:• 81% agreed that most people would not hire a smoker to take care of their children• 72% agreed that most non-smokers would be reluctant to date a smoker• 39% agreed that most people think less of a person who smokes• 21% agreed that most people think smoking is a sign of personal failure What do YOU really think of smokers when you see them on the street? #knowyourself
I think nothing of them if they're in a smoking area, they're just people
People smoke for many different reasons. I smoke too. It's not my place to judge others who have the same habits as I do.
They are just people. Who am I to judge.

I think that if anything, at the very worst, they do it to look cool..or are using it as a coping mechanism for something in their life. This post is rather agitating though, I already feel that non-smokers are some of the most uptight and rude people for being so judgemental.

I agree 10373. I have never in my life judged someone because they smoke, to me the thought that people actually do is literally absurd lol. People who smoke are the same as people who don't smoke. If you're hiring someone to watch your kids that smokes, just make it clear that they aren't permitted to smoke around them, that would be acceptable, but to not hire them solely because they smoke is crazy. The only one of these I could understand is not wanting to date someone who smokes, the only reason I can understand is because if you are a non smoker and have a live in boy/girlfriend that smokes in the house, you are getting that secondhand smoke. But like I said, just tell them not to smoke around you or to smoke outside.
Idk when i see a smoker i think to myself do they got a light and if i dont have a cig then i think hey maybe I should ask if they have one other than that i dont think much of it
As long as there not blowing there smoke in my face they good
Nope. Not really the type to care about what other people think. You don't like smoking, don't smoke. It's simple.

I generally don't care if people are smoking out in the open, however, when I'm at my work, and a medical professional  shows up and he or she is reeking of cigarettes I don't think very highly of them because they could be handling people who are injured or sick and it's not very sanitary. I feel like they could have at least waited till they were not on shift anymore.

data.description: Hi everyone, the next Q&A session will be on Wednesday. See you then!

data.message: #23: Breathing and relaxation techniques can be really helpful when you quit and enrich your daily life. Here’s a link describing a few different techniques -- try one out and tell us how it went. Which one works best for you? #feelinghealthy
Where's the link?
I do breathing techniques a lot and it's quite helpful for when I don't have a cigarette
I take deep breathes and count until I feel calm again. I don't see a link.
I'm familiar with some breathing techniques, I have anxiety and asthma.
I meditate if that counts, I use to do it out in front of this tree at my work but I kept getting nurses pestering me asking me what I was doing.
I cant find the link either

Oops. Tsp forgot to imbed the link. I use a 5-7-8 breathing technique taught to me by nurses on one of my hospital admissions. It really helps if you're stressed or can't fall asleep. Inhale through your nose for five seconds, hold for seven seconds, exhale through your mouth for eight seconds. Really helps, especially if you can't relax. I was told it makes your brain release calming hormones.

At a school I went to, we would practice different breathing techniques before every class to calm and collect ourselves before class started. I often did it outside of class the help with stress and anxiety. I think it would be a really great way to quit and stop using nicotine as my way of calming down.

Hello TSP members! We apologize for forgetting to include the link in yesterday's post. Here it is: http://quitsmoking.about.com/od/cravingsandurges/a/deepbreaths.htm. Thank you for being a good sport and commenting anyways! :)-Shirley from TSP

I liked the second exercise, it was really simple, just breathing in through your nose and exhaling through your mouth. It says you can also say a word when breathing in and after you master the technique you will get to a point where all you have to do is say the word and you will feel that calmness. I am going to start trying this technique, especially when I get a craving.
I would say the 2nd exercise as well
Here's a link for breathing exercises since we didn't get on today question. http://greatist.com/happiness/breathing-exercises-relax
Thanks for the link and i would go with the equal breathing technique or the  progressive relaxation technique
Thank you 10356 for being so resourceful! :D
What is currently your biggest smoking trigger? #TDII
Anytime I'm mad, sad, stressed or anxious. So I would venture to say when I'm upset is my biggest trigger
Thanks for sharing 10365 - yes these are definitely major triggers for many people. Have you ever tried to use alternatives to smoking to cope with upsetting situations? If so how did it go?
After I eat and when I'm in the car are my two biggest triggers.
Hi 10345 - these are also important triggers. What else could you do after a meal or in the car other than smoking? Have you every tried anything?

I was in therapy for 2 years so I've tried using some of my coping methods that I learned but it just didn't work out. We're definitely creatures of habit, I've been smoking for almost 8 years now and it's so hard to break that routine of oh I'm upset so I need a cigarette. That's been my go to coping method for so long.
I hear you 10365, habits can be really hard to overcome and change. In those past 8 years of smoking have you ever had periods when you smoked less or even didn't smoke at all?
Stressful situations or punk shoes
Hi 10356, stress can be a big trigger as well. What is it about punk shows that triggers smoking for you?

I was hospitalized twice and I wasn't allowed to smoke either time but smoking was all I thought about because I was a mad teenager who couldn't have her smokes. There was also a period when I first moved out of my parents where I didn't work for quite awhile so I couldn't really afford to smoke so I did smoke less during that period.

That's very interesting 10365 - so for you these were more or less situations of forces smoking abstinence or reduction. How did you cope with your urges to smoke back then? What worked and what didn't work so well?

In the hospital I was going through withdrawal and was having a really bad time so the nurses gave me nicotine gum which only made my cravings worse. I didn't really cope, I would only get angry and during the time that I wasn't working I was pretty much always looking for change to buy a pack or bumming off of someone. I haven't found anything that actually makes me not want a cigarette, even when I'm sick I still want to smoke. It's a big crutch in my life and I think that's why I have such a hard time. I have a daily routine for my smoking times. When I wake up, when I eat, when I'm driving I smoke way too much, when I'm bored, breaks at work, and I have to have one before bed.
It sounds like the nicotine addiction and habit is really strong in your case 10365. Have you ever thought about using other forms of nicotine replacement or other medication at all?

I refuse any type of medication to help. I'd prefer a natural method but haven't come across any. Nicotine gum definitely does not help. I've considered trying patches but I'm on the fence about spending money on them if they aren't actually going to help.

That's absolutely understandable 10365 - I wouldn't want to spend money on things that don't work either. From a scientific perspective I can tell you that nicotine replacement and other medication can definitely help a lot. But what you are willing to try is of course your choice. Here is a great overview if you want to know about your options: http://smokefree.gov/explore-medications

I think out of all the options I would try patches first. I think we should have a post dedicated to what methods we have tried using so we can hear everyones thoughts and opinions on certain products and get some recommendations!
That's a great suggestion 10365 - I will do that next week!
I have to run. Great discussion today - see you next week!
Driving. For sure. And Boredom. When I'm bored I smoke. A lot.
After eating and when i drink

#22: It’s no shock that tobacco companies spend loads of time and money thinking of how to appeal to a younger crowd with fresher lungs. Check out this document, straight from a major tobacco company. How does it feel to be targeted by a huge, expensive marketing campaign? #beingconscious

I don't really see a difference in how the tobacco companies target us vs how other companies target people. Tobacco companies aren't the only ones who use big expensive marketing to get us to but their products, fast food companies do it, clothing retailers do it ect. It's all about money. So I can't say I feel one way or the other.

Eeessshhhh.  Not very good. And obviously they succeed, as any of us smokers can attest. I still don't blame a tobacco company for me taking up smoking though. I was a legal adult and made the choice to try them myself. No advertising convinced me unless it was so subliminal I didn't even notice it.

I agree 10340. Their advertising is really lame anyways. Tobacco commercials never made me think like, "Wow those people look so cool!" lol the only advertising that affects me in any way, is when the cigarettes have coupons on them to save money on the pack.

As far as my opinion goes, that's capitalism for you, there's always strings being pulled from somewhere with a plan to make money, ethics more often than not put to the side. I don't like it, but at the same time, I don't find myself to be easily persuaded- I'm stubborn and a free thinker. If someone ruins their life over some sort of media, that's ultimately their own fault and not the company's. I don't like what companies do, but the reality is that everyone has a choice. Unless the companies are hiring operatives to sneak in our homes and inject us with nicotine to make us addicted, I have no quarrel. Even then, it's hard to keep children from endangering themselves (with tabacco or whatever else) but that's part of being a parent and should never be blamed on the system if it actually attempts to set up safe gaurds. Whether those obstacles work is usually the matter or someone not doing their job or willingly enabling a child. I'm just gonna stop myself there. I'm too opinionated.
It there a whole document or just this part?
Some companies have proven to be ruthless with their advertising strategies, so I can't say I'm surprised
Honestly it was expected. If I where in there position i would do the exact same thing. Get people hooked young so youll have them buying for ever
It makes since. If someone gets addicted from a younger age they're more likely to continue smoking for a longer time. It's a money game. I don't necessarily like it but, it's business.
Definitely expected because anything retail does the same exact thing. I do agree that smoking advertisements never really enticed me, honestly most smoking ads are really stupid looking.

#21: Flavored cigarettes have been outlawed for years now, yet e-cig companies are using old tricks to gain new customers while they still can. Would you have started smoking at an earlier age if the product you used was flavored like your favorite candy? #ecig
I don't think flavoring would make me want to actually smoke
Honestly no. I waited until I was 18 and away at college to take up smoking. Being away from my family and being a legal adult prompted me to try it. Not the way it was advertised or flavored.

That's a good question. Honestly can't say. I don't feel I would, but I started smoking at a very young age, so perhaps it'd be possible I'd be dissuaded more soon by yummy flavors. But if there were flavored cigarettes now available, I honestly wouldn't want any. I don't smoke for the flavor.
Honestly I can't say if I would have. I started smoking pretty early anyway so I'm not sure how much of a difference it would have made
I feel like I would have, especially if they tasted similar to some of the vape juices I have tried.

I would have to say no because up until I started smoking, I hated it. As a kid I hated the smell and hated when people would smoke around me. I remember once when I was little, I crushed up and threw my mom's cigarettes away. (She was really mad lol) but no I don't think that a flavoring would've made me start sooner. I might've tried it, but I don't think that I would've taken it up. But I also agree with 10351, I first tried and slowly began smoking when I was 13-14, so I was already really young.
Well they e cigs attract younger audiences already because they are so easy to obtain, having candy flavore doesn't help though
No. And if I did I think I would have stopped soon after. I've had flavored Tabacco before and I don't like it very much at all.
Well i started out pretty young with regular cigarettes so I honestly dont know if flavored cigarettes would have made me smoke earlier than I did

#20: Part of the new Tobacco Legislation is that physicians and clinicians must encourage and help their smoking patients quit. Do you think help from a health professional would motivate you to quit? #smokingaffectsall
I'll be 100% honest- no. I don't like people butting into my private life, regardless of what it is or whatever someone's intentions are.
No. I really feel like they don't have my best interest at heart and it's more of propaganda thing.

Yes and no. They don't know your personal reasonings for smoking. They're just going to try and ram the health aspect of quitting and the risks down your throat. So that's why in a sense I say no. Now it would be different if it was a doctor that you have been going to and they know you on a somewhat personal level and are looking out for your best interest, not just because there's a law requiring them to do so. In that sense I would say yes. I also think it depends in the manner that they approach telling you this.
Not at all
My work tried this. And it didn't work because they wanted to charge me 170$. So no it wouldn't, not for me at least
I don't know. It would definitely make me feel guilty about smoking which might help.

Honestly no i dont tend to listen to what most people have to say and in the end its completely up to me, myself, and I to quit. I think as soon as im good and ready ill quit which is coming up very soon
Thanks for sharing your thoughts on this!

Honestly no. Despite being highly motivated to quit, it's my personal choice. Just like beginning to smoke was. I'm aware of the health risks. No disapproval from a doctor will make me stop before I'm ready, heck my own family can't even do that.

I was in the hospital for 4 days and then 5 days with doctors pushing me to quit and it just made me more upset because I didn't need someone to try to fill me with facts about how bad smoking is when I already know the risks and what I am doing to my body.

data.message: #18: Now that you’ve made your list of cons for quitting smoking, let’s consider your top reason not to quit. Post your #1 Con for quitting here and tell us why it’s your biggest concern. You can finish this sentence: "I want to quit smoking, but I'm worried that ________." #beingconscious
"I want quit smoking, but I'm worried that-" I might pick it back up again. That would be my biggest concern.
My biggest concern is having no way to cope with stress, anger, or anxiety. Having to bottle up feelings and stress.
My biggest concern is being unable to find a healthier alternative
I want to quit smoking, but I'm worried that I'll give in to the urge to slap stupid people once I do. Tsp, do you want me to have a criminal record? Lol jk. The anxiety is a big one.
I want to quit smoking but im worried that i might not be able to then once i do how will i socialize with my friends/ make new ones

I want to quit smoking, but I'm worried that I will have really bad mood swings like I said in the previous post. I honestly have never really tried to quit and tried to stick to it because when I want a cigarette and can't have one I feel my blood start to boil and feel almost like a sense of depression. Being bipolar and not on medication really concerns me with that. Smoking really helps to alleviate those feelings.
I want to quit smoking but I'm worried about coping with anxiety and the withdraw symptoms.
It will make my anxiety worsen
I want to quit smoking but I'm worried that I won't have something to use to help calm me down when I have anxiety attacks or if I get upset.
Really legitimate concerns, guys. Thank you for sharing!
#17: All change has pros and cons. What are some of the cons of quitting smoking? Why might it be hard for you to quit? #beingconscious
Smoking helps with my anxiety. It calms me down and helps me relax.
I defiantly use smoking as a crutch for anger or anxiety. I'll have to figure out some better coping techniques once I for real quit.

I'm afraid to quit because I was diagnosed with bipolar a few years ago and I have been doing really good and I haven't taken medication for the last year and a half and I'm nervous that if I quit I'll have trouble with my mood swings again. That is the only thing really making me not want to quit.
I smoke when I drive because driving is boring but also makes me highly anxious. So I know when I stop smoking driving anywhere is going to be awful.
I use cigarettes to calm my self down but i also use it to meet new people
It will be very hard for me to stop smoking because I suffer from anxiety
I also smoke when I drive because of terrible anxiety. I love sitting outside when it's nice with iced coffee, a book and my cigarettes.

I'm actually comforted to know I'm not the only one who uses smoking to cope with anxiety and anger. In the long run, this is my only real hurdle. There's always gum for oral fixation, but I can't think of a healthy alternative that actually works for soothing such extreme undesirable emotions. The fix works within a matter of minutes, if not instantly, so it'll be a hard crutch to give up.
That's mainly why I started smoking. It's really bad though because anytime I become upset, angry or anxious I have to have a cigarette right away and the same rule applies to right after I eat too
there's still a lot of people I see smoking at shows and it makes it hard for me to not want to join them if that counts as a con
It sounds like anxiety is a common trigger for many of you to smoke. Thank you for sharing!

#15: What strategy do you plan to use when you do decide to quit smoking? Will you use any Nicotine Replacement Therapies (like patch or gum)? Medication? Cold turkey? Counseling? Share your plan of action and see if any other group members are on the same page! #beingconscious
I would really prefer to just go cold turkey but with previous experiences I was having a terrible time. I think might try a nicotine patch this time
Patches probably. Maybe gum as a breakthrough? It's nice to dream about just stopping and never starting again, but a lot harder to execute.
I'll probably try to gum. I've done the patches and they don't work very well for me.
I'm going to go back to nicotine gum
Im gonna cut down little by little till i quit. Im also gonna try and stay away from smokers and things that lead me to smoking like alcohol

I'm most likely going to slowly decrease how much I smoke and maybe try the gum. Another thing to help motivate me is when I haven't smoked in a "long" period of time and someone who smokes walks past me and I smell the smoke on them I think it's so gross and then I'm like wow I wonder if that's what I smell like?
I plan on switching to the gum.
I'm going cold turkey because I'm a cheapskate. But I finally convinced my gf to quit too so we're going cold turkey together
Currently cutting back with vapes, but I slip sometimes and I'll admit that. I can't say one way versus another is necessarily easy.
Great plans, everyone! (y)
#19: Who’s that one friend you can count on to listen to you when you need it? Who will you be able to trust as your supporter when you are ready to quit smoking? #support
Lol nobody
My girlfriend is already helping and is the reason I'm quitting - me smoking makes her physically sick.
My bestie tasha love her shes the best always there when i need her
My boyfriend Kerry.
Nobody really. Everyone around me smokes.
My boyfriend Joey
My brother
Sadly all of my friends smoke. I've tried to get me and my boyfriend to stop but he won't so it makes it super hard for me to quit
I think my best friend Lex. She's also cutting down on smoking

Hello folks! Just a friendly reminder: to earn money, you must comment on ALL posts we share each month (every 30 days). You will earn $30 if you commented on all 30 posts, and $0 if you commented on 29 or less. We'll tally your comments every 30 days, and you'll have a new chance to earn money at the start of the next month. You will receive a gift card for the money you've earned at the end of the 90-day program.Let us know if you have any questions! Thanks for your participation :)

#16: Quitting can help preserve our planet! Without cigarette smoke, the chances of household fires decrease and less secondhand smoke is released into the air we breathe. Can you think of any other environmental improvements that might result from less smoke? #beingconscious
The pollution will lessen. The less cigarettes smoked the less cigarette buts that will be thrown out into grass, tress, parking lots ect.

I feel there'd be less immediate pollution from people throwing their cigarettes wherever they please when they're done. Less likeliness for animals to consume them as well, so it'd help protect wildlife.
Fewer cigarette butts polluting public water sources. That's a big problem! Or the butts eventually ending up in the ocean. Then we see how far our impact really goes.
China has a high population of smokers. It would certainly help them

I agree with everyone so far about the cigarette butts.That's a major issue. I also have the theory that if a large number of smokers in the world quit, there'd also be less pollution in the air, right? I mean it would take A LOT of people to quit to notice a change like that, but it's a possibility I assume.
Aww man i took too long to answer and everyone already said all the good ones lol but yeah i agree with everyone elses coment

There was a exhibit at the Muesem in Achorage a few years ago that was completely made up of trash found in the ocean. Within the exhibit there was a glass enclosure that acted as on of the walls filled with millions of cigarette butts. Less smoking would mean less cigarette butts. That's one of many ways that wold less people smoking would ensure environmental improvements.
Less people breathing in our secondhand smoke in some cases
I definitely think the air would be better to breathe and nature wouldn't be so polluted with our cigarette butt trash
What do you guys like about smoking? #TDII
I think it's a nasty habbit and I wish I'd never started
Hi 10351, so for you there are really no positive aspects to smoking. Is this a strong motivator for you to try to kick the habit?
No, there really isnt. I mean it helps with my anxiety some but not enough for it to out way the nasty smell, the yellow fingertips and teeth.
Since we talked last week have you thought more about what would be the best way for YOU to quit smoking?
Sorry I have to run. See you next week!
#13: Do you know anyone who has died from a tobacco-related disease? How did their death affect your own smoking? Post and share your experiences. #reflection
I've never know anyone who had died due to smoking
My grandmother died of lung cancer and my other grandma has emphysema. It adds an extreme amount of guilt to my smoking. Another motivating factor to quit, right?
I've had no experiences like this
No one I know of but I work at a hospital so I've seen a few people who show up for chemo because of lung cancer
I haven't known anyone to pass from smoking.
Ive never had anyone i know die from smoking
I don't personally know anyone, but cancer and strokes run in my family so cigarettes aren't exactly the beat idda.

My Grandpa on my mom's side of the family died from lung cancer. I try not to think about it because I know he would be extremely disappointed in me for smoking. But it is also one of the reasons I started smoking. I remember the smell of his cigarettes. I only got to see him a few times a year. He would take me fishing and smoke while we fished. As much as I hate fishing, the time I got to spend with him holds a very dear and happy spot in my heart. After he died, I swore to myself that I would never smoke and spent many years without coming in contact with anyone who did. When I went off to college, one of my friends smoked and one day I smelled that familiar smell on them after a cigarette break and couldn't help myself. Smoking brings back memories of the time I spent with my grandpa but it also brings guilt because I know it would make him upset.
Thank you for sharing.

I don't know anyone who has died, but I know plenty of people with emphysema and different types of cancer from smoking. It really makes me want to quit but most of the time I have the "it won't happen to me" thought and I know that in itself is dangerous

#11: Everyone wants to know whether electronic cigarettes can help smokers quit. Unfortunately, studies are showing that they are not any more effective than a placebo. So health professionals still recommend using well-studied strategies like counseling or Nicotine Replacement Therapies (patch, gum) when you’re ready to quit. What are your thoughts on e-cigs? Have/would you ever try one? #ecig

I've tried ecigs and my lungs felt even worse from smoking it. I was waking up every morning with my throat burning and I was couching a lot. Plus with ecigs you can still get juice with nicotine in it so really what is the point?

I've tried e-cigs and they made me cough so bad. I always felt really short of breath after hitting one and they gave me terrible headaches. I wouldn't recommend them to anyone, let alone someone trying to quit smoking.

I have tried one (when I was hospitalized and couldn't smoke) it did help provide me with the "fix" I needed to not hurt myself or anyone else near me for that week, but they're not the same as regular cigarettes. And it's still delivering toxic chemicals into your system, just makes you feel better about it. The smell is less offensive though. My family definitely noticed the difference.
I've owned at least three vap pens in my life and none of them made me want to smoke less.
My roommate however, used nicotine patches and he's been off cigarettes for almost 4 months now

I have tried them a few times. They definitely have a less offensive smell and may be less harmful, but I feel like they just make you more dependent on nicotine and it would be easy to switch back to normal cigarettes.

Ive tried e cigs before but never really liked them. Im sure there just as bad as regular cigs but who knows they could be better for you. Ive never tried the gum or patches and im not sure if i would either. Im not too comfortable with wearing the patch all day or chewing on nicotine.
I've tried e-cigs and I find that they're just as addicting as cigarettes, of course that's just my experience

I've tried them and I feel like it's just something to replace smoking a cigarette. It's not kicking the addiction or the habit. You're just getting addicted to something else, and like it was mentioned in a previous post, the BIG TOBACCO companies are making them! So that's a reason I'm not even going to invest into one because it's still profitting them. As far as the danger of it, not only are you still inhaling toxic chemicals, I had one that totally sparked in the part where you put the juice and almost blew up in my face while I was hitting it. So theres also the possibility of that happening! I think they're just as dangerous as cigarettes if not more, but they have a more pleasant smell to them so people think they are safer. I think people are just taking up a new dependence and addiction when switching to them.

I'm probably the only one who feels that it actually alleviates my urge to have an actual cigarette and didn't have any bad side effects. Unfortunately I have to admit the only way it makes my urge to smoke go away is when the juices are high in nicotine, but even then, no nicotine acts as just as much of a replacement, but I need to use it more. I feel it may be less of a placebo effect for me than it is that I have an oral fixation. If I don't smoke, I want to eat, play with my tongue ring, chew on, or suck on something. I've actually done a bit of research on that myself, and it's believed to be linked to stress (agression and even being weaned too early lol) to have an oral fixation. But I acknowledge and can see I have a lot of stress. I smoke mainly when stressed and it used to be worth the immediate fix because I didn't care so much for my health. It's when it started affecting my loved ones health that I knew that it wasn't worth it. Overall, ecigs -feel- like the lesser evil, but I admit it could be no better, if not worse; I frankly contemplate on whether or not the battery system actually radiates our orifices and still can cause cancer.

Another reason I haven't used one to help me quit; not only am I addicted to the nicotine in a cigarette,  but I think I am also addicted to the habit of the actual motion and time of smoking a cigarette. For me, I never know how many puffs of those things is equal to a cigarette so it's never really been helpful to me to erase the urge of smoking a real cigarette.
Thanks for sharing your experiences!

#9: Research shows that emphasizing the benefits of quitting over the drawbacks helps smokers quit their habit for good. Try your hand at making a negative a positive. What’s your comeback for this drawback? #balance
Once the withdrawal is over you will be free :P
I definitely agree. The challenge of withdrawal is rewarded with freedom; the psychological struggle can be coped with, the potential damage from smoking is permanent!
Withdrawal is hard but for every cigarette you don't smoke your heath and breathing improves.
Seeing friends quit heroine make quitting cigarettes look like a cake walk. I think I can handle being agitated for a little while
How about the withdrawal symptoms exacerbated by 10+ years? Quit while you're ahead never had a more serious meaning.
Everyone who has commented has hit it on the head. I think I would keep reminding myself everyday of all the different benefits that are coming my way once I quit.
Thats something ive been woundering about for some time now. What are the withdrawal symptoms? And does everyone get them?

I know I do. There's definitely cravings for the nicotine, I would get super angry at everything and I also had mood swings. I was in the hospital and I wasn't allowed to smoke which drove me up a wall seeing as how I was already mad that I was there in the first place, I finally caved and agreed to try the gum that's supposed to help you quit and for me it only made the cravings worse. It seems that the symptoms are slightly similar to withdrawal from a drug.
And i also agree with every one else's post great job everyone
This is one of the biggest fear about quitting but I know if I make it through I will feel so much better in the long run.

Once you are over the withdraw period you will feel great! I have asked alot of my friends who have quit about that. They always have told me after that third day of no nicotine they feel so much better!
Great points, everyone! :D

#7: Weight gain is one of the top concerns for almost every smoker. We’ve made a list of some tips that can help keep your weight on track while you quit. Pick the one sounds good to you. How could you implement it into your life? #balance • Go for a walk, swim, bike ride or any exercise you enjoy• Find small ways to be more active, like taking the stairs instead of the elevator or parking a little farther away• Find alternatives to snacking, like calling a friend• Drink some extra water
Well I could fit it into my routine by not lying in bed all day
I definitely need to drink more water. I'm pretty much running on Dr. Pepper only.
I could implement drinking more water everyday. Like a glass before every meal so I fill up faster and I could take walks every morning around my neighborhood. It's nice and quite in the morning.
I'm already gaining weight anyways so it's not a big deal. But I've been making diet changes and working out more with my roomstes
Reducing you're daily stress when you quit too will help
This is one of the biggest reasons I haven't stopped smoking. I broke my leg 2 years ago and gained 50 pounds which has made me super insecure. My mom quit and she gained 20 pounds
I'd start out just making the little changes like taking the stairs and parking further away. I'd def like to start drinking more water too!
I already drink a lot of water and i go out for walks every other day. Calling a friend sounds like a great idea. Ive also been trying to go out swimming and exercising as well
I could definitely get more exercise. And water!
Drinking more water would be the best for me. I need to do that anyway. Calling a friend would probably work to.
Thanks for sharing!
#14: On a scale of 1-10 (with 10 being most important), how important is it to you to quit smoking for good? #beingconscious
10! It's proven harmful. It's a horrible habit and I want to quit. For health reasons alone!
Deff a 10
10 for sure.
Absolute 10

I'm gonna answer honestly. Quitting smoking will be nice but I'm still young I have other-higher priorities to attend. I'm not saying that I am not quitting but as for importance I'm going to say a 7.
