data.message: #10: Remember Drawback #1 ('I don't want to have withdrawal symptoms') from yesterday’s post? Which one of our following comebacks works for you? #balance • Some withdrawal symptoms are actually signs that my body is healing• I may be coughing more because the cilia (hair-like structures that line my lungs and clean the air I breathe) that were paralyzed by the cigarette smoke are starting to work again, which makes me temporarily cough more• I may have tingling in my arms and legs because my circulation is improving
All three usually motivate me well
I cough up a lot of gross junk every time I try and quit. It's icky.
Some withdrawal symptoms are signs that your body is healing
The healing one.
The signs of withdrawal being signs of healing is motivational because it shows how hooked your body's chemistry was and gives all that more reason to kick the habit.
I didn't know these things about the first withdrawal. It's actually nice to hear
I like the first one that some withdrawal symptoms are actually signs that my body is healing i never really thought about it like that before

I didn't really know about any of those! It makes me want to quit not only to be healthier but also so that I can test the statements and see if that happens. Its multi-motivational to me...it speaks to the part of me that truly wants to quit bit also the part of me that questions everything lol
Withdrawal symptoms make me realize how terrible smoking is for my whole body

#8: Here are some things to help you maintain your awesome physique when you stop smoking. Which one seems the most helpful? #balance • Make sure you have a well-balanced diet• Chew sugarless gum when you want something sweet• Eat slowly• Plan healthy, low-fat and low-calorie snacks into your day• Watch portion sizes• Read food labels
Eating slowly might help me get sick less
I think a welll balanced diet, eating slowly and and reading food labels to find out exactly what it is you are eating.

I feel planning healthy meals is definitely important. I've actually gotten myself into cooking healthy foods- unfortunately it's easier to buy less healthy foods as organic ingredients are not only a bit more expensive, but perishable, too.

Chewing sugarless gum sounds like a great idea for replacing smoking. I need to start a well balanced diet, eating slower, and watching my portions more. Im not much of a snack person and reading the lables on the food seams a bit boring to me but i might just try incorporating them into my day
Gum! It's a great way to curb your cravings! Eating slowly is definitely one I could improve at.
I do all of these things pretty much except for chewing gum which I don't like. I feel like I've tried everything in the book to quit.
I definitely need to drink more water and watch what I eat better
I eat mostly at work and they are pretty good with their healthy options being an "advendist business" and what not.

Sorry I haven't posted in a day or two...my car broke down and had to go and get financed for a new one...those processes are always fun! So I've been really busy, but I think eating slowly helps maintain your weight and lose weight in every scenario, not just quitting smoking because I have the habit of waiting too long to sit down and eat so when I finally do eat, I eat quickly and more than I would've even needed to feel full because I didnt give it a chance to digest!
Hi everyone and welcome to TSP! I am available for the next hour. Let me know if you have any questions! #TDII
I've got to run guys - check out this study if you're interested http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsa1211128
Also check out these benefits of quitting
#6: What would be the best-case scenario if you quit smoking? #balance
I wouldn't be wasting money on tobacco products anymore
I would be able to breath better, do more activities because I can breath better and I would save a lot of money every year
I'll stop promoting cancer cell growth in my body and be able to save a lot of money in the long run.
my teeth will be slightly less yellow? :p Actually I think my chest will stop hurting and I will feel better overall. That will be the best case scenario for me
Everything will be better! My teeth, my breathing, my health in general, my wallet, and just feeling great about myself knowing that nicotine  doesn't control me anymore!!!

For me the best thing about quitting would be the extra money. The money I use to feed this nasty addiction could be put to much better use. For instance, because I smoke I have no savings.  Having money in my savings account would be nice.
I would save $100 a month and my throat wouldn't feel like garbage all the time.
I would save a ton of money but more importantly i would better my health
Saving money. Smelling better.
#5: Many e-cig companies are actually owned by BIG TOBACCO companies. What do you think their motives are? To have you remain a loyal customer? To help you quit smoking? Other ideas? #ecig

That's very thought provoking. If anything, I feel that it would be a tactic to stay in the game and to remain dominant in sales. There's no saying vapor products wouldn't have addictive additives to them to make them seemingly more desirable. But maybe that's my conspiracy loving side- you never know, people do absurd things for money.
I say its to keep you there loyal customer why whould any company want you to stop buying there products exactly no company would

They just don't want to lose that steady stream of income from us that are addicted. They would find any alternative if they got wind that it might replace cigarettes! I think any product that aims to keep you dependent on a poisonous chemical is a no go.
I think it's too keep people addicted. Whether it be actual cigarettes or e-cigs they are still making money

I'm pretty sure it's to keep customers as well as make new ones. But not thinking in a way like an evil mastermind rubbing their hand together. It's what all corporations do. When organic food became more popular, bigger food industries began making items like that as well. It's pretty much they are hopping on the band wagon.

They're likely just looking to make their money, e-cigs are an increasing trend and they can bill it as a safer alternative until it has been proven otherwise, I doubt tobacco companies would want anyone to quit smoking

I never knew that! I feel like they're doing anything just to keep people giving them money. Even if e-cigarettes make you feel "better," I have no doubt that there's some type of addictive chemical in it, especially since they're coming from big tobacco companies...they're the kings of selling (legal) addicting products!!!
I really think it's just so they can keep making money. Just a business tactic.
Thank you for discussing! :)
I think they had to come up with something new to keep people from quitting all together. Once all the negative info started coming out I'm sure they were panicking to make a new product

data.message: #4: For any of you who aren’t sure what an e-cig is, take a look at this FDA page explaining what they are and some of the controversy surrounding their regulation. If you were a minor, do you think an e-cig would be more appealing and “safer” to try than a traditional cigarette? #beingconscious
data.name: Electronic Cigarettes (e-Cigarettes)
data.caption: www.fda.gov
data.description: Electronic cigarettes, also known as e-cigarettes, are battery-operated products designed to deliver nicotine, flavor and other chemicals. They turn chemicals, including highly addictive nicotine, into...

data.message: I think the e-cigs are a little more harmful and dangerous then an actual cigarette because the exact amount of chemicals and nicotine that's being inhaled can't be determined and it isn't regulated like normal cigarettes are.

I completely agree 10351!! But since I smoked cigarettes regularly even when I was a minor, I don't think that I would've cared too much about statistics and warnings because I was smoking cigarettes anyways. Looking back now, however, I wish I would've listened to every smoker that told me not to start and did some research about not only the chemicals, but also the percentage of teens that start smoking at young age and end up quitting. I mean I know anyone can quit at anytime, although it's really hard, but I wonder if starting as a minor makes it harder to quit as you get older?

Im glade they brought this up because im going through something similer where a relative of mine who is a minor was caught in a picture using one thats kind of like a hookah and when we confronted her she said that she wasnt smoking that all that was in it was flavored water. Clearly she didnt understand that there was way more than just flavored water in it. So after about 15-20min of me explaining it to her she vowed never to use one again. So the point is minors do think its safer than a traditional cigarette because they dont fully understand what e-cigs are and do to your health
One controversy, and I've done the same thing myself so I know where they are coming from, is that e cigs are too easy to take to school. I used to hide one in class and smoke it in the restrooms.

I agree with 10351. I've had e-cigs before and the fact that the nicotine intake wasn't measured in anyway, made it much more dangerous. The first one I had I smoked the entire contents of it in one day. Where as if I had had a pack of normal cigarettes I would have felt guilty about smoking so many cigarettes in one day.
Once upon a time I was a minor that thought e-cigs were safer.
I don't trust ecigs. The. Again I shouldn't trust cigarettes either.

If I remember correctly from my research a while back, the components in ecigs' juices are safe for consumption, but not known to be for terms of vapor being inhaled. To me, it's the same concept of trying to smoke let's say..vegetable oil. It's healthy for other purposes, but smoke is still smoke, and puffing on it doesn't sound smart. However, I may be the only one here who feels vapor is the lesser evil of smoking. To me, the known chemicals in them sound less harmful than the ones in actual cigarettes, and using vapor vs. Smoke, my symptoms with mucus and tight chest have lightened. I do however recognize, there is no saying the chemical reaction being far worse or that somehow vapor radiates our orifices or lungs. All around though, I have to say smoking in whatever form is bad, if not for the way it's consumed, then for the chemical reactions it has with our brain's chemistry. Nicotine is nicotine. Long rant like post, but I tried to cut it back, I'm passionate on this subject.
Smoke is smoke in my eyes and shouldn't be available to minors regardless, they still have developing lungs and even e cigs can be detrimental, or so they say
You guys bring up some great points about e-cigs. Thanks for your comments!
#3: How would you support someone who tells you they want to quit smoking? #motivation
Every time they try and smoke ill remind them of why they wanted to quit in the first place
Well I would work together with them to help them reduce the stress in their life that causes their smoking, on top of that I would help them find things to do that distract them from the urge
Smart
I would help them make a plan. Then help them set a goal and ways to achieve that goal. And support them when they are having a hard time staying on track.

I would show them the statistics for quitting smoking, provide tons of info and help them set up a plan to follow that would hopefully be successful for them. I would keep pushing them until they got to where they wanted to be.

I have helped out a few friends who have quit smoking by reminding them what a they're doing if they try to have a cigarette and I'll take the rest away from them. They would get mad at me but they got over it :p

I am really bad at this. I've had people ask me to help them quit, and none of them have actually quit. I would remind them that they asked me to help them quit if I saw them having a cigarette after the fact and try to keep them occupied with other methods of stress relief or what have you. But eventually it would get to a point where they would say they nnneeeeeeeddded one and I would cave. I've tried quitting with people and outlasted most of them. I guess I'm not the best support system when I comes to that and apparently neither are my friends lol.
Just support them! Quitting is a personal and very difficult decision for a lot of people. Just having the support of a good friend can help someone thinking of relapsing
I feel quitting with someone could greatly help because, at least to me, seeing or smelling someone else smoke makes the urge to smoke a lot stronger.

I would honestly try my best to quit with them since I also want to quit or at least refrain from smoking when I am near or around them because I know for me the smell of a cigarette or seeing someone smoke a cigarette also makes me want to smoke. If they have specific reasons as to why they want to quit I would try to keep reminding them of that. I would also try to have like a task or something for us to accomplish before smoking if they said they wanted one. That usually works for me, or at least helps me to prolong the time from when I want one to when I actually smoke one.
These are fantastic strategies to help someone quit. Thank you so much for sharing them! :)
#2: Educate yourself on the smoking rates and laws in your state. Search up “smoking information” or “smoking bans” in your state. Did any of the information surprise you? #smokingaffectsall
I've noticed a lot more building with an additional sign under their no smoking signs that read no vaporizers

I read the Arkansas laws and the clean air act enacted in 2006. I think it's stupid here in my state smoking in an enclosed vehicle with a child under 6 or 60lbs is only punishable by a 25 dollar fine. What we as adults choose to do with our own bodies is one thing. Who the heck has to be told don't smoke in an enclosed space with your children?
Nope, pretty up to date on all bans in Indiana
I'm pretty aware of the laws in North Carolina. Ours were passed in 2010.

In Alaska smoking is prohibited in all modes of Public Transpotation, all state and government owned buildings while there is a public or private assembly in progress, all schools during the hours of operation, and any restaurant that seats more than 50 people. The thing I founf very interesting is all of these can be voided if the person is doing a theatrical performance in said venue (with authorization of the venue of course).
I've got to do some research, I just moved to Texas, but I was familiar with California's laws.
Nothing surprised me about Massachusetts state smoking laws, I did learn that smoking areas can be designated by the owner of a private business as long as it is not inside the building

I agree with 10356, I've noticed a lot of "no e-cigarettes & vaporizers" signs. Even at places that normally wouldn't need a no smoking sign where it's just kind of a given that you wouldn't smoke there
They raised the legal age requirement to buy tobacco to 21 and banned smoking from most public places
Thanks for knowing your laws!
#1: Share a success that you’ve had in the past. It can be anything from any time. Why did it work? Who helped? #motivation

I got into college, and it worked out because I worked my butt off and made sure that the college knew I was interested in being there, I received help from my best friend and his family, who are essentially my second family
I painted our entire rental property before moving in! Almost all of it solo! My boyfriend and mom helped.
I got finally moved into my own place  last year. It worked out because I worked hard and saved every penny I could and I had a wonderful amazing support team.

Im one of four in my entire family to get my high school diploma. Which would not have been possible without the love and support of my loving mother and thanks to westover job corps where i also received my servsafe and cpr certification's. It worked because I had support and I believed in myself.

I got into the school of my dreams. It worked because I practices my performance everyday before the audition. My friends and family helped by giving me suggestions of things to work on and encouraging me to follow my dreams.

I was homeless and I got a job which I am still working and have been able to afford a place of my own. I got it by going into Starbucks every day and spent an hour or two applying for work and being stubborn as all hell.

I've fostered many animals that I've completely turned their health around, and finally saw to them being adopted. I have a soft spot for the ones who "don't have a chance." I've been fostering since I was about 16, and it's something I'm proud of.
I got my GED when no one thought I would get it!
My boyfriend and I finally got our own place in February and everyone doubted us. They didn't think that we'd be able to do it! We sure are proving them wrong.
Amazing success stories, everyone! :)
Received my first gift card from Amazon today thank you so much

Hello TSP members! Our program will be launching within one week! While we wait for more people to join us, we want you to know that this secret group is a great place to share your thoughts and engage in conversation. Please feel free to like or respond to each others' comments and share any relevant content of your own. To begin, let's take a moment to get to know each other a little better. Feel free to share with us:• Where you come from• Anything about your smoking (how much, how often, when you first started, etc.)• What you hope to gain from participating in the Tobacco Study ProjectThank you! We hope you're as excited as we are!
I'm 10351. I've been smoking for about 14 years now and I'm that this program will help me quit once and for all.

Whats up my names 10354 im from MA i started smoking at the age of 14 im 24 now so 10 years smoking i smoke pretty regularly and i hope to quit and not just for a month or two but forever i want to look at a cigarette and feel disgusted by it

I'm 10340, hello everyone! I'm 23, currently residing in Little Rock, Arkansas however I'm originally from Florida. Started smoking at 19. I'm hoping that this study will help me slow my smoking, perhaps even help me quit altogether! Also the gift cards aren't bad either, just being honest!

I'm 10356, I've been smoking since I was a teen and I smoke primarily at shows or when I'm stressed. I'm wanting to lay off because I feel like I've enabled my girlfriend and I hope to encourage her to quit if I do the same

Hey guys, I'm 10342, I'm 20 and sadly have been smoking for 5 years- luckily though I know have the motivation to quit. It took me to realize that my habits were affecting my girlfriend's health to see it wasn't worth it. I've been cutting back by using a vape and lowering the nicotine level, now when I smoke a cigarette I end up feeling sick..a bittersweet victory in the making. I'm glad to see I'm not alone with the challenge though!

Hello everyone! I'm 10345 & I'm 19. I currently live in Washington, PA but I am from Pittsburgh. I first hit a cigarette when I was 13-ish? And increasingly started smoking more and it became a habit. I have been smoking regulalry, between a half of a pack and a pack a day, since I was 15-16. I'm hoping this study can help me quit for good!!
Thank you so much for sharing! :)

Hi, I know this a couple days late. I'm 10346 I started smoking when I was 18. I'm 22 now. I used to like smoking. It was a social thing at my college. Everyone did it and it was an excellent way to make friends. Now that I don't go there anymore it doesn't have such an appeal. I'm hoping this group will help me give up this awful habit.

Does that include all previous posts and today's post?
Can't wait!!
Yay!

Ive already started cutting down on smoking havent even smoke a cig yet today
Way to go, 10354! :)

data.message: When I have tried to stop smoking in the past I get really intense, horrible shakes. Is there anyway to help stop or lessen these?

Hi 10351 - that sounds pretty uncomfortable! To me this sounds like withdrawal symptoms. How many cigs do you usually smoke each day? Have you thought about using nicotine replacement therapy (patch, gum)? They can really help decrease to withdrawal.
Thank you for your response. I smoke about a quarter of a pack a day maybe a little more. I've tried the patches and they seem to really affect my moods

So the patch would give you mood swings? Maybe another form of nicotine replacement would be a better choice in your case. Have you ever used the gum at all? It's easier to dose because you can just chew one whenever you feel like it and don't have to use it constantly like the patch. What do you think about that?
No I've never thought about the gum as a Simi long term replacement. I've started looking into different brands of the gum. Is there any that you could recommend?
No, pretty much each sort you can get in a pharmacy will be fine. The 2mg gum sounds like a good choice given your number of cigs/day.
Thank you very much Johannes!
Sure! Have you thought about setting a quit date at all?

I've thought about it but I'm hesitant. I've set quit dates before and tried to push myself to be fully quit by then and when I'm not completely quit by then it really brings me down and starts me full blown smoking again.
So do you think tapering down/ gradually reducing the number of cigs you smoke may be a better way for you?

I've tried that too and I do really well with that method until I get super stress or have a lot of anxiety ( I suffer from an anxiety disorder which is why I started smoking to begin with because it seemed to help my nerves better than all the meds they had me on ) and I fall back on full blown smoking again.

Ok, I understand. Yes that does sound stressful! Which approach do you think would be better for you? We can work on strategies for stressful situations over the next weeks as well. How does that sound?

That sounds great!! Thank you so much. I've been talking about quiting with my fiance a lot lately ( we both smoke) but he doesn't really want to quit and I do so it's been a little bit of a stuggle. I think the gradually reducing of smoking is my best method. Also when I've tried to stop in the past I've replaced the oral fixation with peppermint hard candy. This seems to help a little as well but it's really when my anxiety flares that I have a hard time keeping to quitting smoking. That and the horrible shakes I get every time I've tried to quit.
10351 there are also other stop smoking medications that you may want to think about (wellbutrin or chantix). These are prescription only, so you would have to talk to your doctor.

I've thought about Chantix and I've taken wellbutrin for another diagnosis and messed up health more than it helped. I've heard a lot of mixed reviews for Chantix which is why I've hesitated in seeing a doctor for it.

I understand 10351 - you definitely have to decide what works best for you and what you feel comfortable with! We will try to work out the best way for YOU to quit. I've got to run - see you next week!

When trying to quit, is it better to go cold turkey or to cut back gradually? Is there any evidence to support either one?  Also, I've tried the gum but something about it makes my entire mouth sting. Do you know why that might be?

Great question 10346 - I think it depends a lot on your preference. Both methods can work, but setting a quit date and pulling through is easier for many people to stick to, simply because you can't extend it indefinitely like cutting back. But really either method can work. What are you leaning toward?

As for your other question, how did you chew your nicotine gum? Did you follow these instructions? Use the “Chew and Park” method: Chew the gum slowly until you can taste the nicotine or feel a tingling sensation in your mouth. Stop chewing and park the piece of gum between your cheek and gums. After about a minute, when the tingling is almost gone, start chewing again. Repeat this process until the tingle is gone (about 30 minutes).

I've tried both methods. Just flat out quitting seemed to work the best for me but I got headaches and was very on edge until I broke down and smoked. Cutting back is what I've said I've been doing for the past few months so I guess that's not really working at all. Lol. I think setting a date is an excellent plan, the few times I've tried quitting it was really just an in the moment desicion. Usually when I ran out of cigarettes or something.

I did read the instructions on the gum because I was very weary of it. It seemed like an odd thing to me. All it really told me was to chew a piece every two to three hours for 12 weeks. I've never heard of the "Chew and Park" method but I will definitely be giving it a try. Thank you for that.
Yes sure, happy to help! I know many people have problems with the gum because it can be tricky to use correctly. Have you though about setting a quit date at all?

Not really. But I think I will. Does it count as quitting if I go from cigarettes to the gum? Is it safe and/or effective to just use the gum as a way to keep everything function from the sudden cut back in nicotine?
What do you think would be a good day for you? And yes, it absolutely counts to go from cigs to the gum. The gum is definitely safe and should help you reducing those withdrawal symptoms.
